chunks.content:
Driver Hotline & Internal Operations Manual

For Intern Training

Overview

The Driver Hotline & Operations Support role acts as the central communication hub between:

Drivers

Operations

Inventory Control

Sales

Customer Service

Credit Department

This position ensures:

Accurate relay of critical information

Correct handling of operational errors

Proper adjustment of weights, invoices, and credits

Timely preparation and distribution of daily VIP reports

Accurate logging and approval of driver wait time payments

Retrieval of picker information when needed

This job directly affects company financial accuracy, customer satisfaction, and operational efficiency.

Responsibilities by Category

Driver Hotline Email Management

Purpose

The Driver Hotline email is the primary communication channel for reporting driver issues, customer issues, operational errors, delays, wait times, and credit requests.

Daily Duties

Monitor the inbox continuously throughout the day

Read each message and determine:

Does it need to be forwarded to Sales?

Inventory Control?

Transportation?

Customer Service?

Credit Teams

Respond when necessary with clear, professional communication

Log information when required (weight changes, wait times, credits)

Forwarding Rules

Type of Issue | Who It Gets Sent To | Notes
Delivery errors / missing items | Sales and Ops Errors | Always provide route, stop, and invoice #
Weight discrepancies | Inventory Control (James Serrago) | These will be adjusted daily
Pickup-related credits | Credit Department | Include all documentation
Wait time issues | Transportation & HR (via spreadsheet) | Must exceed 15 minutes

Ops Errors (Operations Errors)

Purpose

To communicate and document issues originating from picking, routing, warehouse processes, or loading that cause incorrect deliveries.

Steps

Receive error from driver hotline or sales.

Make note of route, product, invoice #, and issue.

Forward details to Inventory Control (for product-related errors), Sales, and Ops leadership.

Follow up if necessary to ensure corrections or credits are made.

Weight Changes

Purpose
synthetic_questions: What is the main purpose of the Driver Hotline email?
How do I handle weight discrepancies reported in the Driver Hotline?
What if a driver emails about wait time issues over 15 minutes?
For ops errors like missing items on a route, what details do I note and who gets forwarded?
I'm swamped with Driver Hotline emails about delivery errors—who do I send them to and what info is needed? This is frustrating!
chunks.quality_reasoning: Core business process for central operations hub role, detailed procedures and rules with table, actionable steps provided, but chunk cuts off mid-section making it somewhat incomplete

jargon.Driver Hotline: primary communication channel for reporting driver issues, customer issues, operational errors, delays, wait times, and credit requests
jargon.Ops Errors: issues originating from picking, routing, warehouse processes, or loading that cause incorrect deliveries
jargon.weight discrepancies: differences between reported and actual delivery weights requiring adjustment by Inventory Control
jargon.picker information: details on warehouse pickers retrieved when needed
jargon.VIP reports: daily reports prepared and distributed for key stakeholders

wait_time_threshold.context: Wait time issues must exceed this to forward to Transportation & HR

chunks.content:
Adjust catch weight items so customers are billed correctly.

Process Owner:

Inventory Control – James Serrago generates the catch weight report.
You update invoices based on this report.

Steps in Telnet

A. Changing Weights (Invoice Adjustment)

2, 3, Enter order # / invoice #, C Update the weight to the correct value

B. Printing the Updated Invoice

2, 25, M, order #, Enter through, printer #

Credits Processing

Credits come from drivers, salespeople, pickups, weight corrections, and Ops issues.

Sources

Driver pickup sheets (created by Jhanfranco

Sales credit requests

Weight-related adjustments

Ops errors

Customer service escalations

General Credit Entry

Telnet:

8, DRIS, 1, operator ID, customer #, invoice #

Weight-Related Credits

Steps:

Go to: 2 → 1 → I → invoice #

Search for item via item #

On the right side, find the total cost

On the first screen, find the price per lb

Divide total cost by price to determine weight

Enter calculated weight

Document invoice # on sheet

Always starts with “X” for weight credits

Expired Invoices (Over 15 Months Old)

If invoices are older than 15 months, it does not exist in the system

In the invoice field: type X

For item: use 444444 (miscellaneous non-splitable item code)

Add these to a spreadsheet

Send spreadsheet to:

Phil Carson

Sara

Credit Team

VIP Report

Purpose

Ensure important customers’ orders are prioritized for the night shift.

Responsible Parties

Customer Service decides what is a VIP

All new customers are VIP for their first order

Daily Timing

Completed every day at 5 PM

How to Generate the VIP Report

In Telnet:

30, 21, tomorrow’s date

Compiling the VIP Template

Copy data from Telnet into the daily template

Remove duplicates

Double-check each VIP customer’s orders are included

Send final completed list to night clerks

Picker Identification in Telnet

Purpose

Find which picker selected what items in case of errors, shortages, or disputes.

Steps:

27, 36, 4, date, route #, 1st word of customer name

System displays picker information for each item.

Driver Wait Time Logging

Purpose
synthetic_questions: How do I update weights on an invoice for catch weight items?
What's the Telnet process for weight-related credits?
What if an invoice is over 15 months old when I'm trying to process a credit?
The system says the invoice doesn't exist for this credit—it's super old, what do I do now?
How do I generate the VIP report and get it ready for night shift?
chunks.quality_reasoning: Core operational processes for billing accuracy, credits, and prioritization; provides specific Telnet steps but chunk is somewhat fragmented and cut off at end.

acronyms.VIP: Very Important Person (context: important or new customers)
acronyms.DRIS: (Unspecified menu code in Telnet for credits)

jargon.catch weight items: Products billed based on actual weighed amount rather than fixed weight
jargon.catch weight report: Report generated for adjusting weights on catch weight items
jargon.Telnet: Company's terminal-based inventory and order management system
jargon.picker: Warehouse employee responsible for selecting items for orders
jargon.night clerks: Night shift staff handling order prioritization
jargon.Driver pickup sheets: Sheets created by drivers for pickup-related credits
jargon.invoice #: Invoice number used for adjustments and credits
jargon.item #: Item identifier for searching and adjusting in system

expired_invoices_age.context: Invoices older than 15 months do not exist in the system; use special code X and 444444

vip_report_time.context: VIP report completed every day at 5 PM

misc_item_code.context: Miscellaneous non-splitable item code for credits on expired invoices

new_customer_vip_orders.context: All new customers are VIP for their first order

chunks.content:
Drivers are eligible to be paid for wait times of 15 minutes or more, verified through Intellishift. You mark these down in an Excel which you will send to Samantha Cuesta.

Steps:

Monitor Driver Hotline for any wait time emails

Log each instance into the wait time spreadsheet:

Route ID

Driver name

Stop

Length of wait time

Verify using Intellishift data

Send completed records to Sam Cuesta

Sam issues payment approvals

8. Additional Operational Tasks

Communication Normalization

Always relay information factually, with:

Route #

Stop #

Customer name

Invoice #

Issue description

Avoid emotional or speculative language.

Customer History Lookups

If asked about previous POs or customer history: 9, 30 or 9, 3 in Telnet

Importance of This Role

This position ensures:

Accurate customer billing

Prevention of financial losse

Proper credit issuance

Reliable communication across departments

Smooth night shift operations

Historical record accuracy

Reduced customer complaints

Verified driver compensation

This role is critical to overall company performance.
conditions: wait times of 15 minutes or more
asked about previous POs or customer history
synthetic_questions: How do I log and process driver wait times for payment?
What steps do I follow when I get a wait time report from the Driver Hotline?
How do I verify a driver's wait time using Intellishift before sending the spreadsheet to Samantha?
I put all the wait times in the Excel but Samantha hasn't approved payments—what am I missing?
When relaying a customer issue, what specific details like Route # or Invoice # do I need to include, and how do I check past POs in Telnet?
chunks.quality_reasoning: Core operational processes for driver compensation, billing accuracy, and communication; provides clear, specific steps with tools referenced, mostly self-contained for the role.

jargon.Intellishift: Platform for verifying driver wait times
jargon.Driver Hotline: Channel for monitoring driver wait time emails
jargon.Stop: Specific delivery location on a route
jargon.Telnet: System for customer history lookups (e.g., previous POs)
jargon.Communication Normalization: Standard factual relay of info using Route #, Stop #, Customer name, Invoice #, Issue description
jargon.wait time spreadsheet: Excel log for driver wait time instances

wait_time_threshold.context: Minimum wait time for driver payment eligibility

telnet_customer_history_1.context: Telnet option for previous POs or customer history

telnet_customer_history_2.context: Telnet option for previous POs or customer history
